column8: A Refreshing Short Hike to Ramboda Falls
column11: During our journey through Nuwara Eliya, we stopped to visit Ramboda Falls, and it was such a rewarding experience. The short hike down to the waterfall is easy to manage, with clear paths surrounded by greenery and the calming sound of rushing water in the distance. The walk itself only takes a few minutes, but the view at the end is truly worth it‚Äîtall cascades of water surrounded by lush landscapes, creating a peaceful and refreshing atmosphere. It was also nice walking in the river to cross closer to the waterfall, but you have to be very careful because the water comes down very fast and can be dangerous. The water is incredibly fresh and cold, which made the experience even more memorable. You can also go to the top for a different perspective, and then down to the bottom for another view. Both give you beautiful and unique ways to appreciate the waterfall. Tip: Wear comfortable shoes, as the path can be a little slippery in some places, especially if it has rained. Overall, Ramboda Falls is a lovely, quick adventure that gives you a beautiful glimpse of Sri Lanka‚Äôs natural beauty without needing a long trek.

column8: A Stunning Natural Beauty ‚Äì Ramboda Falls
column11: On the way to visit the Hanuman Temple, I stopped by Ramboda Falls ‚Äî and what a breathtaking experience it was! The waterfall is powerful, refreshing, and surrounded by lush greenery. The sound of the water and the cool breeze made me feel so alive and calm at the same time. Nature lovers will absolutely enjoy this place! There are some great spots for photos, and if you're lucky, you might even catch a rainbow near the falls. It‚Äôs a peaceful stop, and the view is truly unforgettable. Make sure to wear comfortable shoes as the path can be a bit slippery.

Ramboda falls has three stages. The center part of the waterfall is right next to the A5 main road a few 100 meters after passing Ramboda tunnel when you are coming from Kandy side. It's s small cascade and not much to look at when there is not much waterflow. The upper part of the waterfall can be viewed after climbing a flight of steps right next to the center part of the falls (on your left). You have to purchase a ticket for LKR 200. Lower part of the falls (and the most majestic) can be viewed by visiting the Ramboda falls hotel. The entrance to the hotel is to your right as soon as you come out of the Ramboda tunnel when coming from Kandy side. There is parking near the gate. From the gate of the hotel, there is a steep descent to the reception area, hence they provide a shuttle (van and a mini bus). Once you get to the reception (which is actually in the 4th floor) they will direct you to a lift which will take you to their restaurant. You can see the waterfall from there. You can also walk across the restaurant and walk about 100 meters and climb down a few steps to get to a viewing platform. [There was also a path to get to the bottom of the waterfall few meters below, but it was overgrown and we went in the rainy season, so didn't go to try that.] You have to pay LKR 100 to the hotel to see the waterfall and this includes the return shuttle service as well. A tuk driver from the area also told that there is a viewpoint accessible by tuk where you can see the top part of the waterfall but the road would not be accessible on the day we visited since it was raining heavily.

The decoration of the room leaves a lot to be desired. Just bare white walls. 2. No bathrobe and slippers in the rooms. But, what is even worse - there is no air conditioning, there is only a fan. 3. There is no adapter (at least one) to Schuko and euro plug in the rooms. Good thing I brought one with me. 4. Breakfast was boring and incomplete. But I am not sure that it is for all tourists and free of charge. I must say that this hotel is probably the best option in Nuwara Elya area. I do not know. Probably for young tourists deciding to stay in the center of Sri Lanka for radial trips this is not a bad option either - there is a pool, wifi, safe, mini fridge and amazing views of the mountains and two waterfalls. As I wrote, the hotel is suitable for an overnight stay as an intermediate point.

Here‚Äôs a comprehensive overview of **Ramboda Falls**, one of Sri Lanka‚Äôs most stunning waterfalls, based on the search results: --- ### **Key Facts About Ramboda Falls** 1. **Height & Ranking**: - Stands at **109 meters (358 feet)**, making it the **11th tallest waterfall in Sri Lanka** and the **729th tallest globally** . - Formed by the **Panna Oya**, a tributary of the Kotmale Oya river . 2. **Unique Features**: - **Twin/Tiered Cascades**: The waterfall has a distinctive **three-tiered or Y-shaped structure**, where two streams (Poona Oya and Ramboda Oya) converge . - **Elevation**: Located at **945 meters (3,100 ft) above sea level**, surrounded by lush tea plantations and misty hills . 3. **Location & Accessibility**: - Situated near **Pussellawa**, between **Kandy and Nuwara Eliya**, along the **A5 highway** . - **How to Reach**: - **By car/taxi**: ~1 hour from Kandy or 45 minutes from Nuwara Eliya. - **Public transport**: Buses stop near Pussellawa; trains to Nanu Oya Station followed by a tuk-tuk ride . 4. **Best Time to Visit**: - **May‚ÄìSeptember (monsoon)**: The waterfall is at its fullest . - **December‚ÄìMarch (dry season)**: Fewer crowds, but reduced water flow . 5. **Viewpoints & Activities**: - **Main Viewing Deck**: Offers close-up views of the cascades . - **Hiking**: A **2 km trail** leads to the top, where a natural pool allows swimming (in dry seasons) . - **Tea Factory Terrace**: Nearby Ramboda Tea Factory provides a higher vantage point . 6. **Nearby Attractions**: - **Ramboda Tea Factory**: Guided tours and tea tastings . - **Other Waterfalls**: Dunsinane Falls, Hellboda Ella, and St. Clair‚Äôs Falls are nearby . - **Nuwara Eliya Town**: Known as "Little England" for its colonial charm . 7. **Legends & Culture**: - Linked to the **Ramayana epic**; local lore claims Ravana flew Sita over these waterfalls . - A **Hanuman temple** with a 16-foot statue stands nearby, a pilgrimage site for Hindus . 8. **Accommodation**: - **Ramboda Falls Hotel**: Offers stunning views of the falls and easy access

Ramboda Falls is 109 m (358 ft) high and 11th highest waterfall in Sri Lanka and 729th highest waterfall in the world. It is situated in Pussellawa area, on the A5 highway at Ramboda Pass. It formed by Panna Oya which is a tributary of Kothmale Oya. Altitude of the falls is 945 m (3,100 ft) above sea level. Rivers, as they flow over uneven ground or down mountains, often split into tributaries or form waterfalls. Sometimes two tributaries of the same river may form twin waterfalls very close to each other as the water spills down cliffs and rocks. However, it is quite uncommon for the tributaries to combine after forming the waterfalls making a Y shape.

Ramboda is the name of the town and there are several waterfalls. Some of the reviews on here are not of the actual fall that most go to see. The beautiful one in the bulk of pictures is found by walking through the Ramboda Falls Hotel. GETTING THERE: You have to go all the way to the bottom of the stairs and then walk along a path.  It is not a 15-20 min hike. It's a walk down a street then down the stairs of a hotel, then along a path that is about 100-200 meters. It can be a bit taxing if you are not in great shape as it is still a lot of stairs.  Also, if you're walking down to the hotel from the road you might find it difficult. From the road, down the hotel stairs over to the falls, is a comfortable 15 minute walk.  There are restrooms in the hotel. I think there is also a lift that you can extra for.  The street down to the hotel is rather steep. THE FALLS: We saw 3 falls in Ramboda.  One was a quick one by the side of the road after the Rothschild tea farm.  Then this one. In the distance you can see a huge waterfall that is likely quite the hike for advanced folk. The one through the hotel, though is likely the one you want to see. On my insta, I'll be posting a video of some of the photo shots that are possible. When we were there, there were a few girls and guys that were clearly doing a photo shoot in front of the falls. I had envy. It's so beautiful and the set up for the shots is soo easy.  When we went it was not crowded, so we could do whatever we wished. TIME OF YEAR:  May is not quite wet and not quite dry season.  The images of people in the water must be during dry season. It would seem rather dangerous during May to go into the water.  The beauty of the falls is kind of independent of the weather season though, IMO. WHAT TO BRING/WEAR: Def bring your photo gear and anything you want for a photo.  Also, I would def wear shoes with good treads in the month of May. Despite a great walkway they've put up, you will end up with muddy shoe wear and it can feel a bit unsteady if you don't have any treads.

On our way to Nuwara Eliya from Colombo, we stopped at Ramboda Falls Hotel for lunch. This hotel is ideally situated to get the best views of the Ramboda Water Fall. Our driver stopped the car on the main road. Many people find it difficult to walk down the steep winding alley to reach the hotel entrance which is far below the road level. The hotel is not even 50 metres from the road, but has a shuttle service to take people to the hotel and back. When we arrived at the hotel, the placed was packed with people. Several tour groups have arrived in buses and they were enjoying the buffet lunch. The hotel staff basically force you to have buffet lunch saying ordering food from the menu can take a long time. We reluctantly took the option of going for the Buffet lunch and found the food to be very ordinary. There were too many people and the food was not being replenished fast enough. We found some of the visitors scraping the bottom of the containers unable to find enough food in them. We found an empty table in a far corner and kept our camera and the handbag on the table to show the table is occupied. We asked for a ginger beer. They have run out of ginger beer and we had to manage with only a bottle of water. We served our food and brought the plate back to the table to find another person sitting at our table in spite of our handbag and the camera. We were not sure how to handle it and luckily for us, the waiter came and asked the person to move to another table. He was a single person on his own. We heard the person arguing with the waiter saying he was occupying the table before we came and they cleared it before he finished eating. Anyway, he has finished eating his desert and left the table without a fuss. I was feeling a bit awkward, but these things can easily happen when the restaurants are over crowded. My advice is that all the people should not leave the table at the same time. You leave at least one person at the table when you go to serve your food. I took a few photos of the water fall from the back yard of the hotel. A few years ago, it was possible to walk right up to the water fall. Now they have put a fence preventing the people getting too close to the water fall. We left the place a bit shaken, but this is one place you should visit when you are on your way to Nuwara Eliya. I am not happy with the quality of the food and my advice is to avoid staying overnight unless you are a keen nature lover and like to explore the area. If possible, avoid the big crowd by not going there during the lunch time. A soft drink or a beer with a side plate like chips or sandwiches is better than their lunch. In any case, you cannot avoid paying extra money for the food, just to have a good look at the water fall and the beautiful scenery around the area.

The Ramboda Ella (Puna Ella) double fall  is unique in the ‚ÄòY‚Äô form where two waterfalls with two water sources merge in to one at the bottom. The water in the fall on the left is from the Puna Oya, A canal which comes through the forest reserve above. The fall on the right hand side is made up from water from Pundalu Oya which flows through cultivated land above. Most of the year the fall flowing through the Pandalu Oya carry more volume but during periods of long drought the role is reversed. The water on flowing on the left fall remains more or less the same while the water on the other fall reduces significantly.

A short walk from the Ramboda hotels to the waterfalls. As you walk down you can spot beautiful wild flowers and the smell of wid herbs welcome you to the steps down as you approach the falls. The walk is not tiring at all. With about 50 steps, I came to see the 200m height waterfalls with its gorgeous view. If you look towards its flowing end we see the water has been channelised. This is for hydel power project which I came to know from our tour guide.

We didn't go through the hotel. Our driver took us to another place to see the falls. You walked up a windy road and some steep stairs and through Sri Lankas amazing nature. This was truley a highlight of our trip

Ramboda falls is a beautiful falls located en route to Nuwara eliya from Kandy. A small walk from the Ramboda Falls hotel, you get to see this beautiful waterfall. Heavy rains during our visit made the falls a picture perfect experience.  Don't forget to sip a tea at the hotel and enjoy the view of the falls and the nature at its best

A short yet refreshing photo-op stop-over before you head to the tea farms and factories. The best way to access it is from the Ramboda Falls Hotel. No fees required. Walk to the viewing deck, sit, relax, listen to its rumbling sound, take pleasure in the beauty of nature surrounding it and take lots of photos.

It was a 45 minute up hill hike up to the top. On the way up, you get different perspectives of the fall. The falls looked beautiful with its full stream of water. There are even places where one can take dip but the water can be cold.
good falls to have a dip. also looks to  be a safe falls. my husband took a dip and me and my daughter just wetted our legs. water was so cold, nice.....
Was a very lovely experience. Was the first time at the waterfall and it's very relaxing to look at.  Fell in love with the nature. Xo xo

Huge amount of water gushing down the water worn gorge.   It is possible to walk down to it from the Ramboda Falls Hotel.  There are a number of falls in the vicinity but this one has the easiest access.

Visited while driving from Nuwara Eliya to Colombo. There is some distance to walk down from the car park. There was not a lot of water, but still the view of waterfall from the bottom is quite good..

A little disclaimer: we were there under a heavy rain that added a big deal to the experience. The experience started with a shuttle drive to the hotel. It's a short drive down an extremely steep and winding road, with an extra bonus of the front window being completely foggy due to the rain and the temperature difference. From the hotel, there is a set of gentle stairs which presumably provide a very easy stroll down to the waterfall in a good weather, but become a waterfall of their own under a heavy rain. Ramboda waterfall itself is quite big, though not particularly picturesque. Climbing up the stairs was even more challenging with so much water flowing down that at some moments it was quite a challenge to move against the stream. A nice little "adventure" in a heavy rain, and should be just a nice walk and several fine minutes in front of the waterfall in a good weather.

This waterfall can be seen when you travel to Nuwaraeliya from Gampola. In there you have to walk around 150 meters to go to bottom of the waterfall. It's really amazing view. There is hotel call Rabboda Falls in bottom of the waterfall you have to go through that hotel.

As we had to stop for lunch and were near this waterfall, our driver suggested this stop. To get close to the waterfall, we could only access it via the Ramboda Falls Hotel. It was a pleasant and very easy walk (about 100ms). There's no entry fee but suspect that buying lunch at the hotel is the payback (no issues with this). I don't recommend this as a 'must-see'   but it wasn't an unpleasant lunch-stop.
From far it is the usual waterfall... But if you do take the walk till the bottom of the waterfall, you will feel the power of this waterfall and you will enjoy the trip... Do stop and visit...

We visited Thuruliya Lodge for the second time in January 2015. The upper two floors of the Lodge had been completed with a very spacious and clean Restaurant at the top level with most beautiful views of the Ramboda Valley and the Water Falls(see the photos I have added to the website). When travelling to Nuwara Eliya, this is a very good place to stop and have a cup of coffee or tea or have the lunch while enjoying the beauty of the Ramboda Valley and the Water Falls. Recommend to get the table onto the balcony of the restaurant to enjoy the views. Newly constructed room No. 304 has the best views of the water falls and the valley. To get the best out of this beautiful place we stayed in the Lodge whole time relaxing and enjoying the unbelievably beautiful views including the Mountains & Valley, Waterfalls, Kotmale Reservoir and the magnificent Sunset. Our room was very clean, spacious and the staff was very friendly and helpful. Unquestionably Thuruliya Lodge was one of the most beautiful places we have ever stayed. Sad to leave the place but sure we will visit again.
there are 2 falls in the village the lower falls an easy walk from the Ramboda fall hotel. The higher fall a good 30 minutes walk from the bridge in the village. Both well worth the time.

You cannot go close to the falls, you can have a view from a distance. Worth for a one time visit. There isnt much in and around apart from the falls. There are couple of hotels close to the falls. Its worth a day trip, dont spend more time than that.

Sri Lanka has lots of waterfalls. This is in a good location surrounded by tea plantations. The walk down is very pleasant as the gardens have been well maintained, but it won't keep you entranced for the day.
Must see place. One of the picturesque waterfalls in Sri Lanka.  You can visit the bottom of the fall without much difficulty and it is on the Gampola - Nuwara Eliya road

I was expecting to go near the water and ger some splashes, but it didnt have any access to go near. They have an area to go and click pics with the waterfall in the background. didnt offer much. A nice restaurant serving buffet.

We were lucky to be travelling thru Sri Lanka after some very heavy rains and this ensured that all the water falls were in full flow! The Ramboda falls was one of the better ones we saw. One can walk up to the view platform at the base of the falls, via the Ramboda Falls restaurant. The steps are steep and at places a bit uneven, so need to be careful. The spray from the water is quite intense, so you will get soaked. The view is good and the drive to falls is gorgeous with tea estates surrounding the area. The restaurant is a good halting point for lunch/tea and has decent bathrooms. If you are travelling in a group, worth asking for a discount on the lunch buffet, they obliged for our group of 15.

We stopped at Rambosa Falls enroute from Kandy to Nuwara Eliya. Very picturesque area surrounded by tea plantations, there's a few steps involved with not a lot of margin for error, but it was worth it.

There are actually 2 waterfalls at Ramboda. One is below the bridge when you cross the river in Ramboda. The other one is a half an hour walk up the hill (the same river). Most people only go to the lower falls, but the upper falls are at least as beautiful as the lower one. The path starts just on the north side of the bridge. Follow the path all the way up. Because it is slippery in places, wear sturdy shoes. Part of the path are steps, other parts are stony and muddy. But is not difficult to find your way In the end you come to a viewpoint with a small building. This is a fantastic viewpoint, one of the best views of a waterfalls we have ever seen (see picture)!!!
I guess its impressive for people that come from countries with no nice waterfalls. It was nice, but not to die for :)
The falls are truly spectacular. If eating at the bottom you can get a free shuttle. Good place for a spot of lunch with good selection of food and drinks.

On our way to our Hotel we stopped at the Ramboda Falls. Incredibly beautiful !   We saw e view from the Ramboda Falls Hotel dining lobby which faces the falls.  Climbing down the base provided a close up view.  Just be sure to take along a hat and apply sunscreen as the sun is strong and can burn the skin; even in January a hat is definitely required.
Very lovely, do not miss neither the falls nor the landscape that leads to them, in a clear day you can enjoy of all the valley around and see the river going down.
Not crowde at all.Its like private island for you.Enjoy. Remember to park the vehicle in proper place as the fall is with the bend and tunnel.

This is an ok stop when you are trevelling between Nuwara Eliya and Kandy, and nede to stretch your legs. Is situated in a beautiful area, but as such not a breathtaking fall. Access thru the Ramada Falls Hotel is a bit odd, but funny.

Ramboda water falls in Sri Lanka is quite a beautiful place amidst the green mountains and tea plantation. We visited this place on our way back from Nuwara Eliya heading towards Kandy. We had our lunch in the Restaurant, with a scenic view of the wild nature and the great Ramboda water falls.

The falls viewed from the Ramboda Falls Hotel open air restaurant, surrounded by tea plantations, are a wonderful sight. If you're eating at the restaurant, watch out for monkeys, they have a preference for bananas!!
The journey towards Ramboda waterfall is amazing. This waterfall is a must visit in Nuwara Eliya.Feel the sprinkle of waterfall as you go nearer.we enjoyed alot.

This area is the most beautiful place in sri lanka. It is breathtaking. If you have to see anyplace in sri lanka visit here for the unimaginable beauty. Nuwara elya is very difficult to get to. A long car ride over very winding roads. Avalanches of dirt on the road. Crazy drivers. Be prepared but the Site is worth it. There are 2 other smaller falls and another small falls on the other side of the hotel. PLUS you see all the tea estates. Hire a driver do not take the train. A driver who knows what he is doing.

To reach ramboda waterfall we drove from kandy to nuwara eliya in a beautiful panoramic hills where every scene is a heaven by itself. To be able to see the Ramboda waterfall you have to access the ramboda hotel. We don't recommend the food though. We reached around lunch time and the food experience wasn't a success. But sitting there and watching the beautiful waterfall and the whole scenery is so relaxing
Water falls in Ramboda is a beautiful location situated in Kandy -Nuwaraeliya road in Srilanka.this is an one of the water falls in srilanka which is very easily can reach to the fall.

we drove through nuwara eliya to see this beautiful waterfalls.. the scenery is amazing. the drive is awesome with lovely views of the vast tea estates.U may want to stay around and spend hours just watching the clouds pass by as the mist covers the estates.

Ramboda is one of he most beautiful waterfall in srilanka,it is in about 40 something km from kandy I usually take this  road(kandy-nuwareliya) to go to hill country with my clients So I want to share some information with you, Not only ramboda,some other waterfalls too,also some beautiful tea mountain views on this beautiful road - Rishan4ever

Access to the falls is via the Ramboda Falls hotel (man, so glad we weren't staying here, talk about 50s kitsch). It's a steep walk from the parking area to the hotel where one has to descend about another five flights of stairs and navigate through the restaurant (reminiscent of a canteen) before accessing the steps down to the waterfall. The falls can be raging during the rainy season, however in our case it was impressive but not spectacular. What is interesting is the small scale hydro electric infrastructure that is set up to power local industry including the Glenloch tea factory we visited (part powered by wood fires too). What is great about the drive in is the many food vendors - we had coconut rotis with palm syrup at a local tea cafe (below the white Rothschild sign set against a cliff face) and ate local fruits sold by various vendors, including durian (a fruit that looks like a sleeping larvae incased in a gigantic oval chestnut, reeking of fermenting garbage ... Creamy, delicious and slightly intoxicating and energizing at the same time.) Nice to see if you're in the area but not destinational in and of itself.
You may think that you can see it when you passing by. Just don't! Stop and see the difference. You need to feel the environment. Look  at it from different antes etc... etc...

Ramboda twin waterfalls and natural pools are located between Kandy and NuwaraEliya. It's a amazing gift to the travelers who love chill weather and virgin, untouched and crystal clear water streams fills the natural pools on it's way to Indian Ocean. It's a rear opportunity to taste cup of tea after tea factory tour, just next to waterfalls in tea garden.

It is a must stop on your way to Nuwera eli.The place is so beautiful that you will feel yourself you are in a European country.I would suggest to stay there for some time with a warm cup of your favourite tea and feel the scenic view,its a different experience altogether.
Amazing feeling. Very cold!! Can have a nice fresh water bath. Try to come up the hill to find a better bathing spot

This waterfalls is on your way from Gampola to Nuwareliya. It is situated amidst a scenic location. But the waterfalls is not much attractive because of less water flow. But, the Ramboda tunnel on the road next to this waterfalls is amazing. Even though it is just 1/8th of a KM in length, it looks great.

A beautiful spot for taking some time to have lunch, relax and then wander down to take photographs. A lovely way to spend a couple of hours Our guide parked at the top of the falls and we got a ride down the very steep hill in a van which was pretty hair raising! You take an elevator up to the restaurant floor which overlooks some beautiful scenery and the falls themselves. Absolutely stunning and the food was pretty good too. We walked down to the bottom of the falls ‚Äì a little path with a smattering of steps. The rocks at the bottom are not suitable for those with knee / hip/ leg problems and require a degree of clambering over. Beautiful location and beautifully kept gardens.
The way to reach down is very hard. Ramboda Waterfalls Hotel ... you can use their elevator to access through. Many monkies in the way. Beautiful view of waterfalls.

The most garbage filled waterfall I have seen in Sri Lanka. So do not look at it closely, but admire it from a distance! Lots of young people seem to go partying there in the evenings, leaving bottles, cigarettes etcetera behind. If you want to go for a serene swim in a beautiful waterfall -this is NOT the place to go! The best way to experience it might be from the Ramboda Falls hotel. The worst place might be from the road passing by it, especially if you follow the path to go "in it" from this point.

We passed these falls with the Kotmale reservoir in the background as we traveled between Nuwara Eliya and Habarana. Small and quite picturesque falls but for the photographers amongst you the entire region provides picture post card views of the mountains and reservoir which I would suggest is one of the most spectacular scenery views in this region. be prepared to take your time and at Ramboda itself there is a short tunnel to go through but consider taking the old road which is only about 50m long but seems to be occupied by monkeys and makes for amusing viewing.

Beautiful falls and spectacular at 109m in height. On the way to the Tea Plantations from Kandy (about 2.5 hours drive). Easy to access, through the hotel and restaurant on site. Then a well built trail to the base of the falls. The best images are before mid morning, as then then the sun blows out the top of the falls and the dynamic range is too great for good even exposures. The best images are from beyond the end of the trail and over the protective fence. Well worth the effort particularly if you are traveling to the tea plantations anyway.

On the way to Nuwara Eliya, this is a place worth stopping and visit the scenic view. Best point to access this is from Ramboda Hotel. You have to walk down some meters to reach the hotel. From Hotel take the lift which will take you further down (Lift can be used only for Hotel Guests- You can have something in the restaurant if you are staying in the hotel). From Life you get a bit further down some meters through some steps, I bet you will find a spectacular view for a perfect photo shoot.

Of the most beautiful waterfalls I've seen in Sri Lanka. And a good location, where there is a restaurant near him.

This waterfall is close to Nuwara Eliya and some tea plantages. It's an amazing place and nobody wants to sell something! When we were there it were just a few tourists. These waterfalls are breathtaking! We stopped at a restaurant overlooking the falls, and we just couldn't take our eyes off of them. The restaurant had beautiful foliage and flowers, and I got a shot of the falls with beautiful pink flowers framing the view. You will want to stand and stare for awhile and take lots of pictures! One of the scenic highlights of our 15 day tour around Sri Lanka!

Ramboda waterfall is on the motorway to Nuwara Eliya, Sri Lanka on the Gampola Nuwara Eliya route. Nuwara Eliya is at an at an elevation of about 6100 ft or 1868 mt over mean sea level and gives the traveller the pleasure of a very scenic drive through Tea plantations, reservoirs, waterfalls, before arriving in this garden city. Ramboda was really the threshold to Nuwara Eliya, with one having to go through the "Ramboda Pass", a rock cut gap on the motorway, from there the real tedious climb begins - this climb is quite rightly called "Top Pass". It is at Ramboda town, one encounters this beautiful Ramboda Falls, which gushes out a broad cascade of water, a sight to behold. Nice place for pictures!
